conclusion: The distance the sky-diver falls between 10 s and 15 s is the area under the velocity–time graph for that interval.
Read the velocity at the start of the interval (t = 10 s): about 22 m s⁻¹ (slightly above the 20 m s⁻¹ gridline).
Read the velocity at the end of the interval (t = 15 s): about 10 m s⁻¹ (the curve meets the horizontal dashed line at that value).

premise: Between 10 s and 15 s the plot is essentially a straight, sloping line.
conclusion: Treat the plot as a trapezoid.

premise: Average velocity over the 5-s interval is calculated using the velocities at t = 10 s and t = 15 s.
Distance fallen is calculated using average velocity and time interval.
conclusion: s = v̄ × Δt = 16 m s⁻¹ × 5 s = 80 m.
The distance is greater than 75 meters.
